Haunted house clich√©s are okay with horror movie fans as long as you show us something new as well. Unfortunately, "Altar," is neither scary nor original.
After much white noise and other loud sounds along with annoying picture fluctuations, the individual horror segments begin. None of them are impressive.
Earth to Atom, come back to us. We miss you.
No doubt about it. Kevin Kline is meant to play Hollywood legend Errol Flynn. It's just too bad that "The Last of Robin Hood" didn't cover more ground.
"The Hunger Games" are almost over. We are near the end. And, I see a world where all are dandified with smelly leotards and jazzy wigs. It's the future, baby.
You may not find many original moments in the corny humor of "Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb." But, you will enjoy time spent with old friends in this third and final film in the series.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A genuinely entertaining feature-length documentary.
"Gone With the Pope" may have a cult audience appeal. I just didn't have the patience to go along with this nonsense.
"Day of Anger" with its rock-solid story and bloody, well-staged gunfights is everything that a lover of spaghetti westerns could want, short of having Clint Eastwood headlining the cast.
movie_title: I Giorni dell'ira (Blood and Grit) (Day of Anger) (Gunlaw) (Days of Wrath) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: James Wan ("The Conjuring") steps out of his genre to supervise traffic and he does an excellent job.
The battle for the Lonely Mountain took way too long.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Despite an authentically enthusiastic performance by Oscar nominee Quvenzhane Wallis, "Annie" sinks and sinks hard with the sounding of more than a few false notes.

"Get Hard" is all the more repulsive because Farrell and Hart are overwhelmingly unfunny. The screenplay shoots for the lowest common denominator and succeeds. It's Easter come early, with eggs laid everywhere.

An animated film should entertain kids, while at the same time, appeal to adults. Frequently, adults are left out of the equation. And, sometimes the action is so frenetic, that only anklebiters get anything out of it. Such is the case with POM.
Go for the special effects, and you may feel blessed. Go for the Bible story, and you may be disappointed.
Horror fans will want to see this grindhouse classic, and I give it a slight recommendation. It's worth seeing once, but be warned. Have your barf bag handy.
The overall vibe I get from "Top Five" is that Chris Rock is a smashing talent. The film, and it's very satisfying conclusion, come from a man with his fingers on the pulse of contemporary comedy.
Bruce Willis sleepwalks through this terrible science fiction film that's short on science, but long on mindless gunfire.
The implausibility of the narrative sinks "Son of a Gun." And, the performances fail to heighten the experience.
"Song of the Sea" is the best feature-length animated film of 2014.
If they handed out awards for misogyny, "Muck" would win effortlessly. Most horror movies are a bit sexist. It comes with the territory. But, this is simply the undressing and mutilation of women.
"The Gunman" is depressingly bad, thanks to its plotting and world-weary cast. They all look overheated and worn out.

"White Haired Witch" is plagued with a copious cast and an overly complex storyline. Keeping track of everyone is difficult and the screenplay is laughably bad in spots, making it even less palatable.
movie_title: The White Haired Witch of Lunar Kingdom (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A low-octane horror film that gets under your skin and stays there. It's hard to forget "It Follows."
The movie, written and directed by Alex Garland ("Dredd," "28 Days Later"), is an outstanding example of what true sci-fi is about and the best sci-fi flick since "Predestination" earlier this year.

If you're content to watch a French-Italian western that doesn't star Clint Eastwood or Lee Van Cleef, then perhaps you might like "Cemetery Without Crosses." A disappointment, yes. But, strangely appealing.
movie_title: The Rope and the Colt (Cemetery Without Crosses)(Une corde, un Colt...) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: Okay, I'll bite. Why did they do it?
A sublimely complex story.
The film is focused on Gore, but Gore is focused on the issues. He makes a convincing case (again).
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: High expectations are not being met.
I'm not sure "Ghost in the Shell" ever had a ghost of a chance. The Hollywood version is too much like a blending of "Blade Runner" and "Robocop."
"Pulse" is the kind of horror movie that genre fans should see at least once. Allow yourself plenty of time and patience. You'll need it.
The great ideas being kicked around in "Prometheus" are nowhere to be found in Ridley Scott's disappointing follow-up.
It's the audience that gets locked into a "deep vegetative state."
The acting and special effects are particularly painful to watch.
The film seem(s) top-heavy, action wise, and a bit awkward.
"The Take" is just your run-of-the-mill Euro-thriller that putt-putts along like a weary TV cop show.
More action and thrills than most summer movies.
It's a horror thriller with some interesting elements and a nice twist halfway through. But, it's where the film goes after the twist that makes it just another direct-to-video "B" horror flick.
Keeping in mind that you "may" have seen it all before, try "The Shallows" on for size. And, don't surf alone.
While I may question the logic from time to time in writer-director James DeMonaco's latest film, I found the overall story surprisingly clear, balanced and even symmetrical.
At least one more TMNJ is on the way. Let's hope for better next time.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Crazed" is one bloody mess, and I'm not just referring to story.
movie_title: Crazed (Fury: The Tales of Ronan Pierce) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In this hateful political climate our nation is experiencing, we need more personal stories like the one told by filmmaker Barry Jenkins.
All films require the suspension of disbelief, but "The Book of Henry" asks too much of its audience.
"Sequelitis" is like the simian flu that's killing off the human population. It's easy to catch. But, director-co-writer Matt Reeves and writer Mark Bomback apparently got their flu shots.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Suburbicon" wants to make you laugh, and it succeeds from time to time.

The special effects are outstanding and the story is a throwback to the days when audiences were given only glimpses of the monster. Sometimes what you can't see or have difficulty seeing is much scarier than something in plain view.
Corny, wildly misdirected and downright ridiculous. But, kinda of fun, too. Maybe you'll like it, maybe not.

Knowing "Happy Death Day" is a "Groundhog Day" retread before seeing it is a positive. You might even enjoy this slasher film more than I did. I found it to be annoyingly unoriginal and tedious. Where's Bill Murray when you need him?

In my younger days, I read every Stephen King novel and looked forward to the film adaptations. There's one major exception and that was "It." I've always had a thing about clowns. Clowns are evil. Period.
Dreadfully difficult to sit through and ultra confusing.
Argento is quoted as saying this wasn't his favorite film creation. Well, never mind that. I like Malden and Franciscus and it's fun watching them fight for justice in an Italian murder mystery.
movie_title: The Cat o' Nine Tails (Il gatto a nove code) (1971)

movie_review_blurb: Wildly outdated and unreasonably dense, "The Foreigner" is not my idea of a good time.
It's an effectively told narrative, well-paced and worthwhile.
Great casting makes a great comedy, and some brilliant strokes are served with the sports dramedy, "Battle of the Sexes."
Less political, but just as unintelligent as the film that went before.
"The Stolen" is pretty much an all-around disaster. The story defies logic at every turn.
The Barry Seal you see onscreen is the man Cruise wants you to see: a guy with limited skills and a lot of dumb luck. It's an energetic and convincing performance.
"No Solicitors" is the unfunniest horror comedy I've seen in many years.
The survival aspects of this mountain adventure are less than satisfying.
It's not chapter-and-verse what happened during Victoria's Golden Jubilee. But, as entertainment, it suffices quite nicely.
A powerful, personal story of how one Cambodian family was impacted by the bloody reign of the Khmer Rouge.
My immediate wish was for a shorter, more exciting film.
Worthwhile animated entertainment is always in short supply, so it's great to see something meaningful like "Long Way North" come along.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: People go into the woods, and they don't come out. Add a man-eating whatsit, and you've got a horror movie. Not a very good horror movie. But, certainly genre fans get what they want, some old-fashioned blood-and-guts. Chomp, chomp.
It's a high-quality horror film, not as good as the original, but exceedingly entertaining.
Moretti personates one of the most sympathetic and likable vampires I've seen in this overworked genre for quite some time.
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Though it may not be all that scary, it gets brownie points for being strange.
"Where to Invade Next" is one of the year's best documentaries. I just hope Moore isn't going soft on us. I miss those fast jabs to the face.
The smartest thing writer/director/producer Andrew Haigh could do would be to pick the two actors he did for the leads in this sensitive, intriguing British drama.
Jason Lee looks dumpy and disinterested throughout. That almost describes my feelings.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Episode 7 of "Stars Wars" is an enjoyable retread, full of great new young actors and returning favorites.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Terminator: Genisys" might have seen less contrived, if Mr. S had settled for a back seat. Instead, the writers strenuously wrote the story for him. And, instead of fresh, we get overly complicated and hard-to-buy-into plot points.
"The Gift" is 2015's best low-octane thriller. Just settle down, sit back and let the events unfold. Things are not what they seem. We know.
Too much time is spent preaching against social activism and not enough time is spent on the actual consumption of humans. It's a cannibal movie, for crying out loud.
The re-invention might have been better as straight-up thriller. More story and less comedy fails would have helped.
There's something familiar about every scene in "Trainwreck." A pottymouth comedy that fails to deliver.
This isn't Guy Ritchie calling. "Mr. Holmes" is a gentle, moving story about a man who desperately wants to remember the past, but can't.
LCD buffoons are competing for a fictional championship against other cartoon characters, this time your stereotypical Nordic types.
A concept film needs much more than the high-pitched goofiness of "Hot Pursuit."
"Unfriended" asks us to spend 83 minutes looking over someone's shoulder at a computer screen. In this tech-fabulous world, we already stare at too many computer screens.
A bit corny, but mostly a chilling and worthwhile experience. Mother Nature is the bad guy in this tale. The humans are all protagonists. All of them.
Extremely well-written and directed by Christopher McQuarrie. Let me repeat. Extremely well-written and directed by the man who counseled Cruise in "Jack Reacher." They apparently click.
"Self/less" takes an intriguing idea and turns it into a silly thriller.
The film understandably assumes that everyone who had anything to do with National Lampoon was a comic genius, but that's simply not the case.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The ending is so farfetched that the suspension of disbelief dies long before anyone in the film ever does.
"Sinister 2" depends greatly on cheap scares.
Poorly executed with awkward line readings and badly sequenced scenes.
Halfway through "Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping," I kinda wished it would stop.
Most of the reasons we all loved the TV specials are well-served by the second film in the series
We need, you Carol Anne. Stay away from the light, dear.

"A Boy Named Charlie Brown" is a fun learning experience. It was for me and millions of other kids in the early 1970's. It has a great message and an uncompromising way of making its point at the end. Kids need this movie.
The superhero world needed better storytelling, a comic touch and more than a few rays of sunshine. The story is crippled by special effects from start to finish.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I like these women for completely different reasons than I liked Bill Murray and his gang. A perfect excuse to escape the heat.
Really missing Raymond Burr at this point. But, it's still good to see Hal Holbrook giving it a go.
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Jealous Jokester (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Hal Holbrook's character kind of grows on you. He's not Perry Mason, but then he's not trying to be.
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Grimacing Governor (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Hal Holbrook playing a countrified version of Perry Mason. Sort of McCloud meets Matlock.
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Lethal Lifestyle (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Paul Sorvino stepping in for the late Raymond Burr. It's the same format that made the Mason movies so much fun to watch.
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Wicked Wives (1993)

movie_review_blurb: These rather routine stories were seasoned with guest stars and familiar character actors. It's nostalgia unleashed. And, I like it.
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Killer Kiss (1993)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderful dose of sentimentality, spiced with Perry's sass, Della's sass and Ken Malansky's bravado and sass, of course.
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Telltale Talk Show Host (1993)

movie_review_blurb: By the way, Shannon ("Boardwalk Empire") is brilliant in the role. I truly admire this actor. He is going to win the Oscar some day. His performance in "99 Homes" should have him a nomination.
"Beasts of No Nation" is a worthy film because it humanizes a real-world nightmare.
Watching this documentary was like listening to an orchestra tune itself. After awhile, you want the conductor to appear.
"The Revenant" is beautifully photographed, but its greatest impact is hampered by an incredibly long runtime (two hours, 36 minutes) and the high improbability of the narrative.

Hollywood must have thought it was worth a shot. "Hard Target 2" attempts to capitalize on the name recognition from the 1993 action film directed by John Woo. But, this direct-to-video sequel is a woeful effort.

"The Homesman" is the kind of film that makes me yearn for the days of John Wayne and Sergio Leone. But, there's one big difference. This is a story that discards nostalgia for cruelty and hardship. It's a western with baggage.
A well-executed feature-length satire stocked with colorful characters behaving badly.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "The Tale of the Princess Kaguya" is beautifully hand-drawn and written with the compassion the narrative deserves.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Guardians of the Galaxy" relied too much on the audience already knowing the Marvel mythology. Call it, in my opinion, an unacceptable shorthand.

On the positive side, there's Vernon and Eggar even being in the film. I enjoy these veteran actors and wish they had more to do. You can also argue the killer's mask is pretty scary. And, at least, the ice skating murder is original.
The lawyer in cell 213 could use half a brain. He's one of the dumbest horror movie protagonists to come along in some time.
Wow, talk about creepy! "Antboy" is a live-action film from Denmark about a 12-year-old wallflower bitten by a super-ant and given prepubescent super powers.
Ambitious, but poorly realized, "Transcendence" is a movie with forward-thinking ideas that fails to gel as a narrative.
Writer-director David Ayer is hoping to unleash that bad guy action-noir vibe he successfully unhatched in "Training Day" and to a lesser extent in "End of Watch." This time, he lays an egg.
An attractive cast and better-than-average thrills make "Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit" a lesser, but worthy entry into the series of films based on the late Tom Clancy's characters.
Nothing creepier than a worm going up your ear canal. But, the new horror flick, "Worm," is more like ear wax. You can't wait to be rid of it.
It's the writing and plotting in "Edge of Tomorrow" that sucks. Not the staging of scenes. Not the film's sense of humor. Not the film's quality action sequences.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: You've got a classic whodunit story with breezy lead performances and darkly humorous plotting.

"X-Men: Days of Future Past" is more than just a gathering of super-heroes. It's a symphony of superbly coordinated action scenes that, as a whole, will appeal to the mainstream, not just the comic book crowd.
"Date and Switch" should have had something new to say about high school friendships. It doesn't.
"M√∂bius" makes the international world of espionage and high-dollar finance downright boring.
Shocked to say I liked "Reel Zombies." It's crude, full of salty language and nudity. And, those are the good points.
We have nasty secrets, a body count, plenty of blood, and no suspense. The movie drags. As we wait for the killer to be revealed, we snooze.
More contrived than clever, "Stage Fright" wants to be the musical version of "Scream." It isn't.
"Robocop" is a remake that manages to find its own way. It may lack the social satire of the 1987 original, but it's sharper and more believable than the film that went before.
Action fans need more than bullets and bodies. "Bad Country" is a disappointment.
What a nightmare! "A Haunted House 2‚Ä≥ is the kind of film that gives lowbrow comedy a bad name. It's just like the original, screamingly stupid.

An overwhelmingly unoriginal thriller. "The Sacrament" borrows heavily, if not totally, from the 1978 Jonestown Massacre. But, it can't get the chills that even a bad documentary on Jonestown could give.
A true waste of time.

The original and only entry in the Wolf Man series that I truly like. Lon Chaney, Jr. was born to play the troubled Larry Talbot, a guy who gets bitten by a werewolf (Bela Lugosi) and openly laments his future as the hairiest man in Europe. Nicely done.
A better-than-average comedy about a woman who turned invisible by a harmless, eccentric old scientist. She has plenty of fun getting even with her boss and dodging incompetent mobsters.
Not one of my favorites.
Mostly forgettable story that employs a relative of the original transparent dude. Yes, taking the potion can make you insane. Been there, done that.
Basil Rathbone plays the title role in this average horror flick about reviving the creature for a second time.
Bit of a bore with Count Dracula nowhere in sight. His daughter reluctantly bares her fangs. Can vampires even have children?
Okay, I don't want to hang the failure of this mega-budget sequel on a single actor. It truly was a team effort. But, Garfield looks most unattractive as the webbed wonder.
If you like period pieces with psychopathic characters, excellent actors and plenty of atmospherics, then you could do worse than a trip to "Stonehearst Aslyum."

Basically the Dracula story set in Egypt. Karloff plays a very wrinkly mummy-come-to-life who like Dracula casts his spell on a beautiful woman, who may be the reincarnation of a long-dead Egyptian princess. Classic horror.
Another undisputed classic from the mind of James Whale.
Bela Lugosi gives his greatest performance as the mesmerizing menace from Transylvania. Dracula chilled audiences in the 1930's, and it still gives me goosebumps.
IF the filmmakers had made a documentary about haunted houses, I might have liked "The Houses October Built." Instead, they opted for a knockoff of "The Blair Witch Project." What a mistake.

There are millions of Christians with average or above-average intelligence. I'd like to think that I'm one of them. So, what possessed the makers of "Left Behind" to produce such an ignorant piece of garbage that's easily one of the worst films of 2014?
In some respects, "The Guest" resembles Hitchcock's "Shadow of a Doubt." Instead of an uncle-niece relationship, you have a fully grown daughter crushing on an army buddy of her late brother.
A good old-fashioned crime thriller. That's what we needed about now. And, "A Walk Among the Tombstones" fits the bill nicely.

One of my favorites, Claude Rains, in the title role. He's only visible at the end, so gaining the audience's favor must have been a challenge using only his voice and plenty of bandages. The invisibility formula drives him insane. Excellent film.
Despite a few bright ideas, "Bordello Death Tales" is plagued by a lousy screenplay, horrible sets and off-the-charts bad acting. It's terribly difficult to watch, even for hard-core horror fans.
Included are the trial and all the trimmings. What's missing is the horror of the event. Except for a few shots of dear old daddy's caved-in face, there's not much gore, even for a TV movie.
Smaug slept through the first Hobbit film, and boy was I jealous.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "I Married a Monster From Outer Space" is surprisingly well-acted. Everyone is dead serious, and not in a campy way as the title might suggest. It works. There are even some genuinely chilling moments.
movie_title: I Married a Monster from Outer Space (1958)

movie_review_blurb: Before there was "Airplane," there was "The Big Bus." The granddaddy of the disaster spoof movies came out in 1976, and despite its unevenness, it's quite the hoot.
"Resolution" is a notch above your average low-budget horror flick. It has the usual gore and scares and head-scratching events. But, the story is what locked me in.
Peter Cushing is over-the-top crazy in this grindhouse-style goreathon. It's hard to imagine the filmmakers didn't know the end product would be campy.
"Machete" was fun. "Machete Kills" gives me a headache.
It's a competent retelling that won't set the world on fire. The high school gym is another matter.
Just enough action to keep it interesting.
Any appreciation of the film will come after it's over and you might say, "oh, that's why that happened." I'm not sure the ending is worth the time invested.
"Fantastic Voyage" is a fun adventure with some incredible sets representing the inside of the human body. What it lacks in reality is made up by beauty and skill.
A bilingual romantic comedy hopes to bridge the ties with a crossover audience, but has only the charm of the leading man going for it.
It's a weird kind of fun.
movie_title: Monty Python's The Meaning of Life (1983)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the return of Brad Douriff as the voice of Chucky and writer-director Don Mancini, this installment lacks the humor or thrills of the films that went before.
What begins as a potentially interesting peek into the seedy world of online gambling quickly becomes a bore. Just fold and walk away.
The scenes where Cage grills Cusack are the best thing about this very average thriller.
The classic MGM musical from 1939 has been lovingly restored and up-converted to 3D.

My generation will never know a film critic like Roger Ebert again. He brought his noble trade to the people and made us all film critics by celebrating his love of movies at a level we could all understand.
The science in the movie is crazy bad. The special effects are cheesy and laughable. But, it's campy and fun.
movie_title: Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea (1961)

movie_review_blurb: What's wrong with "The Hunger Games" and its sequel, "The Hunger Games: Catching Fire?" Well, I just can't get past the buffoonery.

"Delivery Man" is just a tick away from being a typical Vince Vaughn movie. But, surprisingly, there's just enough charm in this film about the joys of fatherhood to make it an entertaining exception to my Vince Vaughn rule.
"Touchy Feely" is light entertainment and well-acted. But, beyond that, pretty shallow.
Kevin Costner would love to have the kind of career comeback that, say, Liam Neeson is enjoying. "Draft Day" won't hurt his chances. But, it won't help them either.

Those merry Muppets are back and on a world tour, no less, in "Muppets Most Wanted." And, while not as good as the 2011 reboot, this follow-up has enough laughs and zippy musical numbers to keep Muppet fans more than happy.
Right out of the headlines, "Narco Cultura" is a documentary that offers insights into the world of drugs and music, north and south of the U.S.-Mexico border.
Oh, no! Not another Syfy movie! Yes, kids. If "Scarecrow" seems familiar, you probably saw it on TV. Now, it's on DVD and can't say it got any better.
They took my daughter. They took my wife. Now, they took my plane? Poor Liam Neeson.
The screenplay is childlike and overly reverential. It's almost as if Clooney is afraid he's going to insult someone by getting a few laughs out of a serious subject.
"The Prey" is an above-average French-language thriller full of suspense and interesting characters.
Nostalgia heaven!
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Murdered Madam (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Who cares if the plotting is a bit obvious and not nearly as accomplished as in the CBS series?
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Sinister Spirit (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Who cares if the plotting is a bit obvious and not nearly as accomplished as in the CBS series?
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Lost Love (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Who cares if the plotting is a bit obvious and not nearly as accomplished as in the CBS series?
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Shooting Star (1986)

movie_review_blurb: This is all about characters you love and seeing them in their twilight years.
movie_title: Perry Mason: The Case of the Notorious Nun (1986)

movie_review_blurb: This is all about characters you love and seeing them in their twilight years.
Not the perfect horror movie, but GORE-iffic nonetheless.
A strong lifting from "Chronicle." A dash of "The Exorcist." And, a weak connection to a previous "Paranormal Activity" sequel. Nothing original going here, folks.
Nicely written and acted. Genuine suspense.
"Out of the Furnace" plays like a less-commercial version of Patrick Swayze's "Next of Kin." The characters are deeper without being complex. In the end, it's just another blood feud.

True greatness. The invisible man was perfect as a behind-the-enemy-lines spy during World War II. Plenty of humor and thrills in this action film, featuring a very recognizable supporting cast, including Keye Luke and Peter Lorre.
A rather dull affair with many scenes directly lifted from earlier Mummy films.
More coherent writing could have helped. That, or a direct line to the Auto Club.
Rains, one of my favorite actors, gives a superb interpretation of the mysterious recluse.

We could chat all day about how "Annabelle" lifted (even stole) bits from better films. But, that would take away from the net effect of this evil doll movie. "Annabelle" is a very good horror film, originality be damned.
When is a thriller not a thriller? When it gets mixed up with a slow-moving coming-of-age tale about an intensely uninteresting teenager.

This sci-fi thriller, starring Scarlett Johansson, romps through space and time, thanks to the fast-paced directing style of Luc Besson. Who cares if it doesn't make sense? Can we have another, please?
The name of the film is "Men, Women & Children." Don't forget the animals, because this one's a real dog.
The self-inflating tale of two immigrant brothers, who join a Chinatown gang as kids, falls woefully short of significance, despite being executive produced by Martin Scorsese.
The brothers take a lean screenplay and turn it into a memorable thrill ride.

Movies can make you feel like a kid again, but this latest entry in "The Mummy" franchise is so base that only a pre-pubescent boy with limited intelligence might be interested. Even then, I wonder for how long.
movie_title: The Scorpion King 4: Quest for Power (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, if it wasn't for the salty language, this might just be a TV movie. But, I liked it.
An honest, gentle performance by Sarah Snook is not enough to recommend this clich√©d ghost story.
A handsome thriller with plot twists that don't always make sense, "The Two Faces of January," moves slowly, but ultimately entertains.
Director Mike Leigh and actor Timothy Spall paint their own masterpiece.
Yes, this is one of those low-budget gems you're always hearing about. Sub-par production values, certainly. But an intriguing story with excellent acting.
Pardon me for not indulging filmmaker Paul Thomas Anderson again. "Inherent Vice" is shamefully incoherent and a waste of talent.
If intriguing science-fiction thrillers make you tick, then "Predestination" may be one of the best films you see in 2015.
Any documentary can be slanted to a particular point of view, but most filmmakers try to be a bit more subtle. Cry me a river, "Dinosaur 13."
Probably one of the most unusual coming of age films you'll ever hope to see.
Another silly exercise in bad acting and cheesy special effects.

"The Green Prince" is a dramatized documentary based on Yousef's autobiography, "Son of Hamas." And, while I don't particularly care for reenactments, I do believe Israeli filmmaker Nadav Schirman did an excellent job of bringing Yousef's story to film.
The plot of "Open Windows" sounds like a great idea for a high-tech thriller. But, the end product, unfortunately, is just a confused mixture of contrivances that don't add up.

You've gotta really be willing to throw logic out the window to enjoy "Big Driver," a revenge-thriller based on the Stephen King novella. But, as TV movies go, it isn't that bad and certainly the cast is excellent.
A well-written, well-directed movie an average person like myself can grasp. If I want a more complicated explanation of the universe, then I can refer to Hawking's book, "A Brief History of Time."
As a kid, I enjoyed this movie much more than I do as an adult. ALL those great Universal monsters in a single film. Even Dracula shows up. But, these days, FMWM seems contrived and dull.
For every joke that works, there are five that don't.
"John Wick" is all about the action, a beautifully choreographed ballet of bullets, knives and deadly punches. It's also a triumphant return to the action genre for Keanu Reeves.

If the point of the film was to make you dreary and uncomfortable, mission accomplished. But, since I can't accept that people really act this way, then spending time with such dispassionate characters is meaningless and improvident.
An emaciated Gyllenhaal plays Louis so adroitly, he must have been always intended to have this role. He snares the audience with his character's dark charm and floors you with his inhumanity.
Does "Kingsman: The Secret Service" have a secret right-wing agenda? I couldn't get that thought out of my mind while watching this visually taxing and noisy spy spoof.
Director Michael Cuesta does an admirable job with a capable cast.

"Dracula Untold" is the story of how one man tried to save his homeland from an invading army. It's not about Bela Lugosi feasting on tender white necks in polite society. If you can get past this, then you might enjoy this origins story.
"Ouija" is one of those low-octane horror flicks you watch once and forget.
An extremely satisfying undersea adventure with a quality lead performance by Jude Law.
Moore's performance as an early onset Alzheimer's patient is arguably her best. And, that takes into account four earlier Oscar nominations. She is due.

The best thing I can say about "The Judge" is that I didn't mind watching it. The movie, starring Robert Downey, Jr. and Robert Duvall covered a lot of familiar territory, but it was a comfortable journey.
I needed a little something to lift my spirits, and I found "My Old Lady" did the trick.
"Mas Negro Que la Noche" made me shudder in fear; fear that it could get worse with each passing frame. And, it did.
movie_title: M√°s Negro Qu√© La Noche (Darker than Night) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What are you going for here, David Ayer? Authenticity, or a glorification of war? In "Apocalypse Now" we marveled at Marlon Brando's character, but was he a hero? I don't think so.

This dreamlike film, directed by twelve graduate students from New York University, fails to make celebrated American poet C.K. Williams much more than a mildly interesting daydream. Despite its top acting talent, it even inspires a deeper sleep.
"No Good Deed" made some decent box office and didn't cost much to make. Perhaps there'll be a sequel. "Good Samaritan Goes Bad" or "Call Triple-A, Cause I Ain't Opening the Door."
Hard to imagine anyone else in the role of singer James Brown than actor Chadwick Boseman. He nails it.
In a weak year for feature-length animated films, "The Boxtrolls" was clearly the best in my estimation. That doesn't sound like much of a recommendation, but it truly is.
If I ever watch this film again, I will time the sequences showing the creature swim underwater. Swim, swim, swim, swim, swim. Very repetitive and definitely not scary.
Long, dull and silly. Truly a pain to watch.

movie_review_blurb: Okay, it's just a guy in a rubber suit. Even people in the 1950's weren't afraid of this so-called monster. But, there's some camp value to this on-the-water and under-the-water adventure.

movie_title: Abbott and Costello Meet the Invisible Man (1951)

movie_review_blurb: Another monsterpalooza. But, this time, a major bore.

movie_review_blurb: Fans of the comic book will probably be pleased and thrill seekers in general will get plenty to chew on.

One of the few must-see films of this summer.

movie_review_blurb: You're definitely getting more bang for your buck; too bad most of the bangs look alike.

A huge waste of celluloid.

A taut, compelling thriller that slowly sneaks up on you and nails you to your seat.
A truly moving experience, and a perfect example of how art -- when done right -- can help heal, clarify, and comfort.

While it's doubtful that Eminem could run out and perform Shakespeare tomorrow, his talents on screen -- in this role -- are astounding.
Once again the production values -- the sets, costumes and props -- are pure perfection.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: There are no romance, no humor, ultimately nobody to care about in this oddly sterile movie.

movie_review_blurb: There's a heavy stench of 'been there, done that' hanging over the film. It's everything you'd expect -- but nothing more.
A truly wonderful tale combined with stunning animation.

The Two Towers does not disappoint. This film is a fitting companion to the astounding The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: One long adrenaline shot that never takes itself seriously and never pauses long enough to worry about making much sense.
Scorsese is at the peak of his powers.
Norton and Lee make a great team.
A classic case of a bad, bad movie happening to perfectly good actors.

A bleak and unsparing look at the mind of a schizophrenic man, played brilliantly by Ralph Fiennes.
Diehard fans of any of these stars [Martin, Latifah, Levy, Plowright and White] may be amused -- the movie is, at times, an amusing diversion -- but most will probably find it wanting.
Wildly entertaining from start to finish.

It's an experience that's deeply human and profoundly moving.

It will warm your funny bone if given half a chance.
This is Depp's film from beginning to end, and he's fascinating to watch.

Every bit as good -- if not better -- than the original.
A tremendous waste of Academy Award-caliber talent.

An utter delight.

A delightful dark comedy.
A movie the whole family can enjoy.
A riveting story with complex situations and extremely well defined characters.

The best big-screen adaptation of a John Grisham novel since The Firm.

One of the best films I've seen this year.

Utterly breathtaking.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: [Minghella] once again has achieved the miracle of transforming a difficult book with an inner narrative into a deeply satisfying film.

A refreshing change of pace; however, the movie doesn't sustain a promising start.
Compelling viewing.

An airy, nostalgic celebration of roller disco.

A script that offers few thrills and a slapdash story.
An uneven effort.
Reminds us of the curative power of art in an ugly world.

[A] low-flame comedy.

Stale slapstick and predictable, raunchy sight gags (usually involving a banana).

Quite certainly one of the most bizarre and multivalent films I've ever seen.

movie_review_blurb: The film presents a devastatingly airtight, dramatic argument.

Director David L. Lewis presents a warm, informal portrait of this dynamic, white-bearded New Yorker.

This summer's Master of Disguise.

movie_review_blurb: The movie works overtime to be crowd-pleasing, effectively using the tried-and-true tale of an innocent man wrongfully imprisoned thanks to the duplicity of the corrupt and powerful.

A wonderfully acted, wickedly funny and provocative film that contains an intriguing and perceptive glimpse at loneliness.

Perfume is not gratuitously violent, nor does it focus on the act of murder itself. There are numerous suspenseful and creepy scenes showing Jean-Baptiste at work, but, primarily, the movie is the study of a troubled human being.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: We Are Marshall is manipulative and hokey and formulaic, and, often, overly sentimental. But it is also nearly impossible to dislike.

It's loud and boisterous, and features plenty of slapstick and bodily function humor. And, at shorter than 90 minutes, little ones shouldn't get antsy.

movie_review_blurb: It talks a good game, but it's unconvincing.

It doesn't reinvent the wheel and is fairly lightweight, but it features a steady stream of solid laughs and goes down easy.
A recycled and contrived romantic comedy that suggests that no matter what else she might have going for her, a woman cannot have true happiness without a husband.
Spectacular performances and a series of frighteningly tense sequences elevate it above your typical Hollywood mystery.

Exceptionally superficial. There is hardly any mention of the music itself. The members never once discuss how they feel about their music, what it means to them or what messages they are trying to send.
The biggest problem with "Paranoia" is Hemsworth. While he has leading-man looks, he has very little charisma or screen presence.
An absurdly profane comedy that spends its entire time serving up filthy jokes and then trying to top them.
